repnme.cdata!:
China - Second Loess Plateau Watershed
            Rehabilitation Project; First and Second Xiaolangdi
            Multipurpose Project; and Second Tarim Basin Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The ratings for the Second Loess Plateau
            Watershed Rehabilitation Project of China were as follows:
            outcome was satisfactory; risk to development outcome was
            moderate; Bank performance was satisfactory; and Borrower
            performance was highly satisfactory. The ratings for the
            First Xiaolangdi Multipurpose Project of China were as
            follows: outcome was highly satisfactory; risk to
            development outcome was significant; Bank performance was
            highly satisfactory; and Borrower performance was highly
            satisfactory. The ratings for the Second Xiaolangdi
            Multipurpose Project of China were as follows: outcome was
            highly satisfactory; risk to development outcome was
            significant; Bank performance was highly satisfactory; and
            Borrower performance was satisfactory. The ratings for the
            Second Tarim Basin Project of China were as follows: outcome
            was satisfactory; risk to development outcome was moderate;
            Bank performance was highly satisfactory; and Borrower
            performance was satisfactory. Lessons learned from the
            projects included: 1) The Bank needs to elevate its
            engagement in China's water resources policy
            discussions above the provincial level to emphasize the
            perverse incentives that are created by extensive
            agricultural water subsidies; 2) Monitoring and Evaluation
            requires capacity building and reorientation to measure
            outcomes and impacts; and 3) Much greater care is required
            in dealing with issues of attribution when estimating
            ex-post economic rates of return.

repnme.cdata!:
China - Second Xiaolangdi Multipurpose
            (Stage II) Project

abstracts.cdata!:
Project ratings are as follows: Project
            outcome is highly satisfactory; sustainability is highly
            likely; institutional development impact is substantial;
            Bank performance is satisfactory; and Borrower performance
            is highly satisfactory. The Xiaolangdi project (stages I and
            II) is the largest Bank-financed project in China to date.
            On the international scale, it was a very challenging
            project because of its huge size, predominantly large
            underground caverns, high degree of technical difficulties,
            and complex subsurface conditions. Principal lessons learned
            from the Project include the following: a) High risk/high
            reward projects can be effectively implemented with the
            right skills on the Bank side, and high commitment by the
            client to good organization and competent management,
            combined with the judicious use of international technical
            assistance and review. b) Implementing a project of the
            magnitude and complexity of Xiaolangdi will be greatly
            assisted if the implementation organization is in place
            prior to the start of the project. It should be independent,
            have full decision-making authority and be accountable and
            responsibility for implementation performance. c) The
            separation of the large and complex technical and civil
            works construction activities from large resettlement
            activities into two separate project operations worked very
            well and contributed to the effective and successful
            implementation of both. It allowed both the Bank and the
            implementation agencies to concentrate their resources and
            efforts on the two activities, as separate operations. This
            provides valuable lessons for the Bank on how to manage
            large-scale resettlement associated with a major
            infrastructure investment. d) The establishment and
            maintenance of effective forum for communications amongst
            various parties (owner, engineer, designer, advisors and
            contractors) should be actively pursued from the onset, to
            avoid misunderstandings that could cause delays and /or
            losses to the project. Communication difficulties were
            perhaps the most difficult to resolve in construction of the
            Xiaolangdi scheme. e) The use of the International Panel of
            Experts substantially reduced the time for resolving
            conflicts in understanding technical problems. (f)
            Experience suggests that an International Panel of Experts
            for environmental management was necessary to ensure
            successful implementation of EMP, especially for large-scale
            projects with significant environmental management risk. g)
            The use of the Environment Supervising Engineer and
            International Environmental Panel clearly demonstrated that
            all environmental issues were observed early and corrective
            actions were taken. h) The use of Disputes Review Board to
            resolved claims issues proved to be extremely useful and
            resulted in most claims being expeditiously resolved. i)
            Training of staff on all aspects of implementation prior to
            the start of the project - scheduling, construction
            supervision, contract management, claims management and cost
            control averted many of the problems and issues encountered
            in the project, especially with the international
            contractor; j) Training of staff prior to completion of the
            project in financial management, business management and
            tariff negotiations added significantly the sustainability
            of the project.

China - Xiaolangdi Multipurpose Project :
            Stage II

abstracts.cdata!:
The objectives of the Xiaolangdi
            Multipurpose Project: Stage II are to: 1) provide flood
            protection for 103 million people in the North China Plain
            in rural areas, several large and medium cities and major
            industrial centers; 2) control sediment accretion in the
            lower reach of the Yellow River for a period of about 20
            years; 3) generate much needed  hydropower; and 4) supply
            irrigation water (and increase the reliability of
            irrigation) for some 2 million hectares and ensure more
            stable water supplies for downstream cities and industries.
            The components of the projects are the following: (i) dam
            and structures, which include preliminary-local works, dam,
            inlet, outlet, power station, turbines, gates, metalwork,
            generators, switchyard, contract administration and
            consulting services; (ii) training; (iii) environmental
            management plan; (iii) flood, sediment, ice and drought
            management; (iv) institutional support for the Yellow River
            Conservancy Commission; and (v) institutional reform training.

repnme.cdata!:
China - Xiaolangdi Multipurpose Dam Project
            Stage II : environmental impact assessment (update)

abstracts.cdata!:
This is an update of an environmental
            impact assessment (EIA) of the Xiaolangdi Multipurpose Dam
            (XLD) Project, Stage II. The project's overall plan and
            its components remain essentially unchanged from that
            described in the 1993 EA (report no. E30). The XLD project
            is designed to protect downstream population settlements,
            farms, and infrastructure from the hazards of disastrous
            floods; and to achieve a major expansion in downstream
            irrigation, providing sufficient electric power and water
            supply to support urbanization/industrialization, to enhance
            estuarine ecology, and to expand aquaculture. The
            environmental protection components include the relics
            protection program; the disease control and protection
            program; dam stability against earthquake hazards; air,
            water, and land quality impacts; and impacts on natural
            vegetation and animals, on rare and commercial species, and
            on villages around the sites. A detailed archeological
            exploration, classification, and salvage program has been
            undertaken to locate, recover, and protect important
            underground and surface relics and cultural treasures in the
            area to be inundated. After excavation, objects with value,
            like earthware, stoneware, etc. will be repaired and stored
            in museums. The rest, like tomb, ash pit, etc., will be
            recorded in writing and photographed for further study.
            According to the evaluation, the main components of objects
            with historical values will be removed and relocated, if
            possible, and those which cannot be removed, will be sampled
            and recorded. A number of serious public health concerns,
            especially communicable diseases, pose significant problems
            if protective measures are not taken. The project could
            significantly increase the hazards of malaria, encephalitis,
            hemorrhagic fever, and enteric diseases. Measures for
            control of mosquito vector diseases in the construction zone
            include: medical screening of all workers; periodic spraying
            of all buildings in construction work areas and camps; and
            periodic monitoring of pertinent mosquito species larvae.
            The hemorrhagic fever control program is based on
            controlling mice and rat density; and includes medical
            screening examinations and annual examinations for all
            construction workers. The mitigation program for enteric and
            other disease control in the construction zone involves
            maintaining sanitary conditions in the construction work and
            living areas, including safe water supply and adequate
            liquid and solid waste management, and air pollution
            controls. To address dam safety in the event of earthquakes,
            a special seismoscopic network is needed to carry out
            seismic monitoring, allow information feedback, and provide
            proper earthquake prediction. The assessment determines that
            either minimally negative or -actually- positive effects
            will result from the Yellow River's lower flows and
            less turbid water for the following: freshwater fishery,
            water quality, land accretion, landslides, reservoir
            seepage, development of the wetlands, and changes in
            biodiversity. Reservoir formation will inundate sizable
            deposits of mineral resources, but the only potentially
            significant loss would be of coal; however, because the coal
            lies beneath impermeable shale strata, some mining of it
            will remain feasible after inundation. Among the number of
            rare and protected species in the reservoir and in the
            surrounding area, only waterfowl will be directly affected,
            their populations possibly increasing. A properly planned
            flood control system includes not only constructing and
            operating physical flood control works, but also flood
            forecasting and an emergency response system. Finally, a
            detailed resettlement plan is elaborated.
